content:
Hi @T-compiler/meeting; the triage meeting will happen in about 1h45
WG-prioritization has done pre-triage in #t-compiler/wg-prioritization/alerts and prepared the meeting agenda

We will have checkins from:

  • @WG-diagnostics checking by @Esteban Küber and @oli: anything to share?
  • @WG-rustc-dev-guide checkin by @Santiago Pastorino and @Joshua Nelson: anything to share?
hi @T-compiler/meeting ; the weekly triage meeting is starting now. Add a :wave: to show that you're here!

We'll start off with 8 minutes for

Announcements
• Tomorrow (Friday 18 March) we will have a retrospective on the March memshrink sprint. see compiler-team#412
• the USA has ended daylights savings for this year, and due to govt shenanigans from years ago, our DST is out of sync with that of the rest of the world
(that's my explanation for the time @apiraino wrote above.)
• Next week 25.03 the new stable release 1.51 is out
which reminds me: There is a PR that I had intended to land on beta: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues?q=is%3Aopen+label%3Abeta-accepted+label%3Abeta-nominated
@simulacrum did I miss the cutoff there?
hm, no, I don't think so?
okay just checking
(I only mention it now because I noticed, due to the issues P-medium status, that we won't be talking about it otherwise in today's meeting)
MCPs/FCPs

• New MCPs (take a look, see if you like them!)
    • "LLVM plugin support in Rust" compiler-team#419

• Old MCPs (not seconded, take a look)
    • "MCP: More Cranelift-friendly portable SIMD intrinsics" compiler-team#381
    • "Debuggable Macro Expansions" compiler-team#386
    • "Uplift the invalid_atomic_ordering lint from clippy to rustc" compiler-team#390
    • "Staged queries" compiler-team#391
    • "Do not traverse the HIR to generate metadata" compiler-team#392
    • "Embed version numbers in backport nominations and regression labels" compiler-team#393
    • "Add different entry points for x.py" compiler-team#396
    • "rustdoc is using rustc_ast_pretty, would it be possible to make it somewhat "stable"?" compiler-team#403
    • "Eagerly construct bodies of THIR" compiler-team#409
    • "Lang Item for Transmutability" compiler-team#411

• Pending FCP requests (check your boxes!)
    • "Adding diesel to the cargotest suite" rust#81507
    • "reduce threads spawned by ui-tests" rust#81942

• Things in FCP (make sure you're good with it)
    • "Filter out query machinery from compiler backtraces by default" compiler-team#410
    • "MCP: Embed the hir_id of the _awaited expression_ into DesugaringKind" compiler-team#413
    • "Switch JSON serialization from rustc_serialize to serde" compiler-team#418

• Accepted MCPs
    • No new accepted proposals this time.

• Finalized FCPs (disposition merge)
    • "Emit errors/warns on some wrong uses of rustdoc attributes" rust#80300
    • "Implement Extend and FromIterator for OsString" rust#82121
    • "slice: Stabilize IterMut::as_slice." rust#82771
WG checkins
@WG-diagnostics by @Esteban Küber and/or @oli : do either of you have something to report here? (Okay to just say "nothing to report")
Likewise, @WG-rustc-dev-guide : anything to report, @Santiago Pastorino and/or @Joshua Nelson ?
Nothing of note
we forgot to write up our check in :upside_down: working on it now https://hackmd.io/MmEUn2jMSSuNtKj-rjNWNA
no problem @Joshua Nelson

pnkfelix said:

Likewise, @WG-rustc-dev-guide : anything to report, Santiago Pastorino and/or Joshua Nelson ?

we can report it at the end of the meeting, I've been a bit sick these days
Sounds great. We'll just move along with meeting for now
Backport nominations

T-compiler stable / T-compiler beta

  • No beta nominations for T-compiler this time.
  • No stable nominations for T-compiler this time.
T-libs-impl stable / T-libs-impl beta

• "Fix io::copy specialization using copy_file_range when writer was opened with O_APPEND" rust#82417
    • opened by @The 8472
    • approved by @Mara
    • Fixes #82410, P-critical regression when streaming one file into another and the writer is in append mode
I noticed comment from @Mara saying that this was not critical, but the issue it fixes was prioritized as P-critical
I have to note here: Its note great when so much of the diff in the commit is refactoring
makes it hard to quickly see what the effective change is
I guess I should write that on the PR since @The 8472 isn't on this stream.
Since this did break someone on stable, I'd vote to backport.
yeah we should backport
(the actual change, in case people care, is the addition of EBADF to the list of error codes that cause fallback to io::copy)
#82417: beta-accepted
(and I left a comment saying so, including label)

• "Fix io::copy specialization using copy_file_range when writer was opened with O_APPEND" rust#82417
    • issue is also nominated for beta backport
I don't think there's a good reason to stable backport this
s/beta/stable sorry for the typo
what?
this is the stable vote

pnkfelix said:

I don't think there's a good reason to stable backport this

You mean to actually stable backport this or to ship a new stable version?
I thought that comment was just pointing out that its the stable vote for the (beta0 backport we just discussed?
oh
@Wesley Wiser okay that's a reasonable point
that's correct but it was ambigous. anyway nothing really important
we can stable approve and let the release team decide what that means
(I agree I wouldn't ship a new stable release for this either but that's probably up to t-release)
right, okay
Arguably if we ever adopt a Long-Term-Support system
where old releases get updates
then we'd need to have that kind of protocol in place
(where we would approve stable backports for the LTS)
fine, stable approved

• "std: Fix a bug on the wasm32-wasi target opening files" rust#82804
    • backport of a fix by @Alex Crichton
    • fixes #82758, a P-high regression breaking loading files when compiling for --release and LTO enabled
    • assigned to @Mara
    • waiting for approval
so this has now merged onto master (its not awaiting approval anymore)
we already discussed it and delegated to T-libs-impl to decide about a backport
@Mara are you around?
maybe we didn't make that delegation sufficiently clear, but there was a comment about it on the PR...
I admit I'm a little nervous
it landed 4 days ago in nightly. If we land it in beta now, it is effectively landing it in the release for next week
but then again the issue its fixing is a stable-to-beta regression
so ... okay, I guess beta backport approved
(under theory that whatever harm this might do, it has to be better than the harm of the bug it is fixing)
beta-backport approved
For me, I guess I'm not super worried since this is already broken on wasi. It seems like at worst, it will simply continue to not work.
after the next stable release would fixing that imply a further point release?
@apiraino are you asking about #82804?
yes. (not sure the Q is relevant)
well perhaps this is a symptom of our unclear/timing-dependent terminology
I believe what we are discussing is a backport to the 1.51 beta
which would then become the 1.51 release next week
if it doesn't get into the 1.51 beta, then that would be a point where we would need to talk about a stable backport
I interpreted the question as "if this doesn't fix it, then the bug becomes a stable-to-stable regression"

Wesley Wiser said:

I interpreted the question as "if this doesn't fix it, then the bug becomes a stable-to-stable regression"

thank you! you worded the question way better than I did :)
but its been confirmed that this fixes the bug, by the issue filer. So I am still confused
if the bug were not fixed by this PR, then yes, any further work to fix the bug after next week would be fixing a stable-to-stable regression.
but that's a hypothetical scenario that I do not think we are in
(what I was worried about was if pushing this change injects a new bug)

(which @Wesley Wiser pointed out: Any bug injected by this should only affect code paths that were already hitting the stable-to-beta regression in the first place. So in principle there's no way this could make things any worse. (Famous last words.))

pnkfelix said:

well perhaps this is a symptom of our unclear/timing-dependent terminology

@simulacrum I assume there must be open action items from our previous discussion about fixing the terminology here, right?
Well, at least, the code only touches -wasi stuff so the absolute worst case should only be that the -wasi target is broken for this release.
hm
yeah maybe, not sure
(it could be as simple as: "Felix, stop saying "beta backport approved" in your comments. Say "1.51-beta approved", etc.)
(and likewise the agenda construction system could incorporate the appropriate version numbers, etc.)
And given that it's Tier-2, as long as it builds that would meet the minimum stability commitment
I think we should probably move on :smile:
yes sorry I was busily fine tuning my words

T-rustdoc stable / T-rustdoc beta

  • "Fix "run" button position in error index" rust#82979
    • opened by @GuillaumeGomez
    • approved to @Nemo157
Seems fine but also :shrug:
@Joshua Nelson you were right to push @GuillaumeGomez about what this is fixing
Beta backporting this seems fine, I don't think it needs a stable backport
but a beta backport effectively means its going to be stable in a week?
why is this such high priority then?
@pnkfelix I was asking about the change to rustdoc.css, the rust.css change is fixing the error index
Guillaume has a screenshot of the change
It's not high priority IMO
The bug seems small but so is the fix ...
I guess the point that is so crazy low risk
:shrug:
fine, I guess
Small bug, but highly visible
but its been there for ages?
ugh its just costly even debating it
my struggle here is that I don't like the precedent these approvals set
Let's not approve then
If this is already broken there's no great rush to fix it
okay
Yea, we don't ususally rush things that have been broken forever and especially not if they are mostly annoying and not problematic
okay done
Sgtm - note that @simulacrum is the one who nominated for backport, I think guillaume was confused how static files are distributed
right I understand
it was fine to discuss it
excpet of course that I myself said it was costly to debate it
@simulacrum feel free to argue the point, though I suspect you were just acting as proxy for @GuillaumeGomez
moving on
omg how is it 44 minutes in
• No stable nominations for T-rustdoc this time.

PRs S-waiting-on-team

T-compiler

• "add dynamically-linked musl targets" rust#82556
    • opened by @Ariadne Conill
    • assigned to @nagisa, raises some concerns on the behaviour consistency
    • assigned also to @Vadim Petrochenkov, provides a great summary on Zulip, suggests to enable dynamic linking on nightly to see what breaks
    • @richfelker (author and mantainer of musl) recommends proper naming to avoid confusion
    • @Wesley Wiser opened a compiler-team#416 meeting proposal
we have a design meeting about this
so we won't discuss in this meeting

T-libs-impl

  • No PRs waiting on T-libs-impl this time.

Issues of Note

Short Summary

  • 0 T-compiler P-critical issues
    • 0 of those are unassigned
  • 63 T-compiler P-high issues
    • 40 of those are unassigned
  • 0 P-critical, 3 P-high, 3 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-beta
  • 1 P-critical, 1 P-high, 2 P-medium, 0 P-low regression-from-stable-to-nightly
  • 0 P-critical, 37 P-high, 89 P-medium, 10 P-low regression-from-stable-to-stable

P-critical

T-compiler

  • "probe-stack=inline-asm generates wrong DWARF information" rust#83139
    • issue is labelled as high/critical on reporter's end, breaks compiling their cpu profiler
    • reporter mentions root cause to be PR #77885
    • reporter also is testing an LLVM patch from @nagisa which seemingly fixes the problem
    • could this be a release blocker?
I'm having difficulty believing this could be a release blocker, to be honest
but maybe
We could maybe beta-backport a revert of PR #77885 ?
since PR #77885 was fixing stuff on non-tier-1 platforms ..
@simulacrum thoughts on ^ ?
hm
not sure
I don't really know how critical dwarf info is
feels nice to fix, but backporting llvm always feels risky
the patch also hasn't landed yet
i'm inclined to defer/not backport
wait
I'm not talking about backporting their LLVM fix
I'm talking about reverting this: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/77885/files#diff-9fabbb6c2a9866adc57cd380e3cbfa18991cf7327364edd1ffe996a4c1db0249R134
under (admittedly hasty) assumption that __rust_probestack would still work on LLVM >= 11
hm
I don't know enough to say I think

pnkfelix said:

We could maybe beta-backport a revert of PR #77885 ?

So, I kind of like this idea but I'm not sure this is going to be resolved in the next 6 weeks as the upstream LLVM patch hasn't been accepted yet.

simulacrum said:

I don't really know how critical dwarf info is

I agree with this: I don't think we make any guarantees about the reliabilty of our dwarf info today, unfortunately
And I'm not sure we want to be on the hook for reverting this until it's fixed upstream

Wesley Wiser said:

pnkfelix said:

We could maybe beta-backport a revert of PR #77885 ?

So, I kind of like this idea but I'm not sure this is going to be resolved in the next 6 weeks as the upstream LLVM patch hasn't been accepted yet.

is that an argument to revert PR #77885 on both beta and nightly ?

Wesley Wiser said:

And I'm not sure we want to be on the hook for reverting this until it's fixed upstream

oh. Why not?
maybe I need more context about the value added by PR #77885
I'm not sure broken dwarfinfo is more important than this change.
@nagisa are you around? You've been involved with looking at this
My understanding is that #77885 is necessary work towards resolving #43241
okay, let me rephrase things
We have a release in a week
what is relative harm of: 1. reverting #77885 in beta to buy us time, vs 2. breaking dwarfinfo for stack probes on stable
Its an honest Question
I think we should followup outside the meeting and get @nagisa or some other llvm folks to say. I think i'm loosely convincing myself that reverting #77885 for at least a cycle seems not bad.
and I think I mostly agree with mindset of "sorry, we don't make enough guarantees about our dwarf today to support the tool you are making"
Perhaps my objection to 1 is not entirely logical. We've certainly done that before in the past without any real harm that I recall
I think buying time is good
okay I'll assign myself to #83139 to put up a PR reverting #77885 (or at least emitting __rust_probestack unconditionally; not sure about the other changes in PR #77885)
I'm around now.
next

T-libs-impl

  • No P-critical issues for T-libs-impl this time.

T-rustdoc

  • No P-critical issues for T-rustdoc this time.
@nagisa (maybe I'll followup with you about this later)

P-high regressions

P-high beta regressions

  • "WASI: path_open regression in Rust 1.51 when using LTO" rust#82758
  • "major performance regression between Rust 1.50 and beta when using target-cpu=native" rust#83027
I don't think we should revert personally, but happy to chat later too.
we discussed rust#82758 already
i looked at rust#83027 earlier in the week and saw that others were making progress on it, it seemed
nothing much since the confirmation that this was injected by PR #80749
This needs to be reverified.
Since the PR to fix handling of -Ctarget-cpu=native has landed.
what PR was that?
ah PR #83084 ?
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/83084
yeah
so we need to reach out to @BurntSushi to confirm if that fixes things?
and maybe beta backport PR #83084 ?
Sounds about right.
lets take dcare of this now
Adjust -Ctarget-cpu=native handling in cg_llvm #83084
(feel free to say "beta-approved pending confirm from burntsushi that it fixes bug")

To give a short summary of the tradeoffs: this problem only affects a small number of people using a very specific flag combination which isn't a default and has been known to break in other ways in the past (miscompile)
(I added :sushi: emoji to represent my previous comment)
The PR is also pretty large so I myself am pretty :sushi:-to-:shrug: on this.
(as far as I know there is no way to combine :fire: and :sushi: )
fine. Lets just go with decline to beta backport
(aren't we over-time?)
probably
its "only" a performance regression
I'll keep spitting out remainder of agenda items
but, thanks to everyone in @T-compiler/meeting for attending! sorry for letting digressions get out of control

Unassigned P-high nightly regressions

  • No unassigned P-high nightly regressions this time.

Performance logs

triage logs for 2021-03-18

Added two benchmarks over the past week to the perf suite - diesel and stm32f4,
which are intended to add to the level of tracking for rustdoc and, for both, a
focus on compiler trait machinery.

Performance results for this week are mixed, but overall largely positive.

Triage done by @simulacrum.

3 Regressions, 3 Improvements, 4 Mixed

Regressions

Shorten rustc_middle::ty::mod #82964

  • Moderate regression in instruction counts (up to 4.0% on full builds of deeply-nested-check)
  • Largely limited to diesel-doc builds, but a big regression there; left a nag
    to followup. Likely caused by a change to inlining.

Allow calling *const methods on *mut values #82436

  • Very large regression in instruction counts (up to 11.3% on incr-full builds of packed-simd-check)
  • Unfortunate and unexpected regression. Left a nag.

Turn -Z incremental-verify-ich on by default #83007

  • Very large regression in instruction counts (up to 15.1% on incr-unchanged builds of issue-46449-debug)
  • Expected mitigation, essentially part of a soundness fix (though due to other
    bugs in the compiler - this just adds asserts that catches those).

Improvements

  • Eagerly construct bodies of THIR #82495
  • Iterate on crate_inherent_impls for metadata. #83082
  • Tweaks to stable hashing #83064

Mixed

  • Store HIR attributes in a side table #79519
  • Enable MemorySSA in MemCpyOpt #82806
  • Don't implement mem::replace with mem::swap. #83022
  • Rebase and fixup #80493: Remove MIR assignments to ZST types #83118
@simulacrum any nags this week for performance triage?
yes? not sure why they're not in agenda I guess
there were two
found 'em

https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/82964#issuecomment-800663588
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/82436#issuecomment-800668093

Nags requiring follow up

  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/82964#issuecomment-800663588
  • https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/82436#issuecomment-800668093

simulacrum said:

yes? not sure why they're not in agenda I guess

yup, my bad (sorry)
seems like #82964 might need more guidance.
(maybe about what tools to use to identify inlining candidates? Not sure.)
@osa1 seems responsive to nags on PR #82436

Nominated Issues

T-compiler

  • "undefined reference to linker error when using dylibs" rust#82151
    • mentioned in PR S-waiting-on-team
(I've been discussing #82151 a bit with @Alex Kornitzer )
(I'm still trying to figure out what the scope of #82151 is, in terms of rustc's role in it.)
I have some time set aside to keep looking into it; its just fragmented a bit.
T-libs-impl

• "Use getrandom for generating HashMap seed" rust#80149
    • Opened by @Artyom Pavlov
    • assigned to @Steven Fackler, raises a question about the policy for adding getrandom as new std dependency
    • @dhardy describes how the evaluation process could be
    • @Mara labeled for T-libs-impl discussion
(seems entirely in T-libs-impl wheelhouse)

• "Is there a gentler way to land the assert_matches macro?" rust#82913
    • opened by @anp raises a question about the level of breakage assert_matches!() introduces
    • Discussed in T-libs meeting, outcome is to remove it from the prelude and re-add it in the next edition
    • @simulacrum leaves this nominated to allow release team to chime in and comment
(again, entirely in T-libs-impl wheelhouse I'd say)

RFC

  • No nominated RFCs for T-compiler this time.
okay so that's all the agneda items. Sorry again for running over time

here's the dev-guide check-in, sorry it's late

2021-03-18

  • Continuing to work on a walkthrough of the compiler
    - Added support for -Z unpretty=ast to the compiler rust-lang/rust#82304
    - Added support for -Z unpretty=thir rust-lang/rust#82860
    - Working on adding support for -Z unpretty=hir to playground rust-playground#683
    - At some point we would like to add -Z dump-metadata or similar

Most notable changes

  • Add article on using WPA to profile rustc memory usage on Windows #1074
  • Switch from Travis to GHA #1073
  • Fix date-check comment formatting #1066
  • Add Oxide paper to bibliography #1056
  • Use more accurate estimate of generated LLVM IR with llvm-lines #1049
  • Update docs from date triage for 2021-02 #1048

Most notable WIPs

  • Fix rust compiler meeting info #1087
  • rewrite ty.md #1057
  • improve glossary page #1053
  • Add a section on keeping things up to date in the git section #1031
  • Document lang items #978

• At some point we would like to add -Z dump-metadata or similar

@Aaron Hill let us know that something like this already exists with -Z ls, but it's not complete

Draft for next week's agenda:
https://hackmd.io/UZ8VFdqFT0mJtGRnm-Lwmw?view

Scheduled checkins:

  • @wg-incr-comp checkin by @pnkfelix and @Wesley Wiser
  • @WG-llvm by @nagisa
